Caption: Native American protesters stand outside the Phoenix office of Yandy.com, a retailer of "sexy Native American" costumes on Wednesday, Oct. 24, 2018. For some ethnic and racial groups, Halloween has long been haunted by costumes that perpetuate stereotypes and instances of cultural appropriation.

FILE - This Sept. 21, 2017 file photo shows Megyn Kelly on the set of her show, "Megyn Kelly Today" at NBC Studios in New York. Kelly is apologizing to her NBC News colleagues for questioning why dressing up in blackface for a Halloween costume is wrong. She faced a swift backlash for her morning show segment on Tuesday, Oct. 23, 2018, and wrote later that she realized that such behavior is wrong. She says she’s never been a “PC” kind of person, but does understand that she needs to be more sensitive on issues of race and ethnicity. (Photo by Charles Sykes/Invision/AP, File)

Posters at the University of New Hampshire campus in Durham, N.H., encourage students avoid Halloween costumes that can be seen as racially or culturally offensive. A woman walks past the Fillmore Blues Evolution mural in S.F.’s Western Addition, which like other historically black Bay Area neighborhoods, has lost scores of low-income black families.
Reina Tello and her daughter, Alyssa, 10, stand in front of the home in S.F.’s Bayview two days after they were evicted.
Credit/Source: Photo: Yalonda M. James / The Chronicle 2018

Caption: Juana Ines Tello straightens a banner that reads "Defending my roof is my right" in front of her home at 1778 Newcomb Ave., in the Bayview District, in San Francisco, Calif., on Wednesday, September 19, 2018. Tello and her family were evicted from their home of 18 years.
Credit/Source: Photo: Yalonda M. James / The Chronicle

Caption: Juana Tello stands in front of her home at 1778 Newcomb Ave., where her family members and friends are packing up their belongings in their home of 18 years, in the Bayview District, in San Francisco, Calif., on Tuesday, September 18, 2018. The family is facing a forced eviction, a battle they've been fighting for eight years. A new study shows the effects the Bay Area's astronomic housing costs are having on racial and ethnic groups. UC Berkeley researchers looked at the demographics of every neighborhood in the Bay Area from 2000 to 2015. Increases in housing prices intensified racial disparities in access to neighborhoods with better environmental quality, educational resources, and economic opportunities, increasingly placing these neighborhoods out of reach for low-income people of color in San Francisco, Alameda and Contra Costa counties.
Credit/Source: Photo: Yalonda M. James / The Chronicle 2018

Caption: Juana Tello, 32, holds legal documents, with notes taken during an appearance in front of Judge Teri L. Jackson, outside of the San Francisco County Superior Court in San Francisco, Calif., on Tuesday, September 25, 2018. Unrepresented by a lawyer, the Tellos had a court hearing against Aurora Loan services, but the hearing couldn't proceed because of a $400 sanction against the family. The Tellos were evicted from their house, located at 1778 Newcomb Ave., in the Bayview District.
Credit/Source: Photo: Yalonda M. James / The Chronicle

Caption: Golden State Warriors forward Kevin Durant (35) against the Los Angeles Lakers in the second half of an NBA game at Oracle Arena on Saturday, Feb. 2, 2019, in Oakland, Calif. The Warriors won 115-101.

A federal appeals court in San Francisco granted the Trump administration’s request Wednesday to reconsider its ruling that ordered a ban on the widely used farm pesticide chlorpyrifos, a chemical that, according to recent studies, can cause brain damage in children. In this photo taken Aug. 4, 2009, a crop duster sprays a field of crops just outside Headland, Ala.

Caption: San Francisco Mayor London Breed discusses safe-injection sites in September next to state Sen. Scott Wiener and Assemblywoman Susan Eggman, authors of legislation that would allow San Francisco to operate such a site for three years.
U.S. Attorney William McSwain has sued to stop a nonprofit from opening the nation’s first supervised drug injection site to address Philadelphia’s opioid problem.
Clean needles are available to drug users at the Cactus safe-injection site in Montreal.

California State Auditor Elaine M. Howle, right, listened as UC President Janet Napolitano testified in 2017 at a hearing in Sacramento. Howle’s audit found that Napolitano's office collected at least $175 million it did not properly disclose to the regents.
UC President Janet Napolitano (right) appears before legislators in 2017. The state auditor says Napolitano has not implemented transparency reforms.
Parker Spadaro, right, a student from the University of California, Davis, joined others attending a legislative hearing looking into a state audit of the UC Presidents office in 2017.
Aalayah Eastmond (center), a survivor of the Parkland, Fla., mass shooting, testifies on gun control at a House hearing.

PEBBLE BEACH, CALIFORNIA - FEBRUARY 05: Ho Sung Choi of South Korea plays a shot during a practice round prior to the AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am at Pebble Beach Golf Links on February 05, 2019 in Pebble Beach, California. (Photo by Cliff Hawkins/Getty Images)
Ho Sung Choi tees off in a practice round before the AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am. He will play for real Thursday at the Monterey Peninsula Country Club.

PEBBLE BEACH, CALIFORNIA - FEBRUARY 05: Ho Sung Choi of South Korea plays a shot during a practice round prior to the AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am at Pebble Beach Golf Links on February 05, 2019 in Pebble Beach, California. (Photo by Cliff Hawkins/Getty Images)
Ho Sung Choi’s quirky swing was enough to lead Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers to ask to be placed in a foursome with him at the AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am.

Caption: This is a 1976 sketch of a man, nicknamed the Doodler, who is suspected of killing six gay men in San Francisco during 1974-75. The case has not been solved and San Francisco homicide detectives released an age-enhanced sketch on Feb. 6, 2019, in an effort to gain new ground in their investigation. This photo ran Jan. 20, 1976.

Debi LaBell loads groceries into her minivan at the Whole Foods Market in Redwood City, Calif., on Saturday, January 26, 2019. LaBell, an independent contractor, works for grocery delivery service Instacart on weekends for extra money. She is upset  about a way Instacart has changed payments which she says results in lower wages.

Caption: Instacart shoppers, who are typically independent contractors, get paid by the “batch.” The company previously lowered per-delivery payments to account for tips shoppers received from customers. On Wednesday it announced it would raise minimum payments and not factor in tips.

Becerra has used his post atop what some call the “Resistance State” to pummel President Donald Trump’s administration with dozens of legal actions. He may turn up the heat even more, buoyed by his overwhelming endorsement from voters, a Democratic U.S. House and a new, more aggressive governor who takes office Jan. 7. Richard Chenery injects heroin he bought on the street at the Insite safe injection clinic in Vancouver, B.C., on Wednesday May 11, 2011. Insite, North America's first and only legal injection site, promoted by its founders as a safe, humane facility for drug abusers, is now facing a court challenge from the Conservative government that sees it as a facilitator of drug abuse. The case opens before the Supreme Court of Canada in Ottawa on Thursday, May 12, 2011 and has drawn international attention. (AP Photo/The Canadian Press, Darryl Dyck)

Caption: Gordo Taqueria, which operates on S.F.’s Clement Street and four other Bay Area locations, has agreed to pay $690,000 over allegations of wage violations.

An attorney for Gordo Taqueria, which operates on Clement Street in San Francisco and four other Bay Area locations, wrote: “When the class-action complaint was filed at the end of 2016, Gordo and its counsel proactively engaged plaintiff’s counsel in negotiations and early alternative dispute resolution, and the parties worked hard to negotiate a deal that is believed to be reasonable and fair to all parties. Finally, the allegations in the complaint have been categorically denied by Gordo.”

Opponents of SB277, which eliminated the personal-belief exemption California parents used to skip their children's mandatory school immunizations, protesting in 2015. The bill passed, and its author, state Sen. Richard Pan, survived a recall attempt. Child vaccinations have increased in California as a result, but there are still many pockets of low vaccination rates in Northern California - leaving the Bay Area vulnerable to disease outbreaks like the measles outbreak that was been declared a public health emergency in Portland, Oregon, this month.

CEO Susan Ehrlich says S.F. General Hospital will do a better job of informing insured patients that they may qualify for financial assistance and set an out-of-pocket maximum for patients.

Zander Brandt, who rents an apartment with his wife on the outer edge of the Mission District, thought he was saving money by walking to S.F. General Hospital when he was experiencing severe stomach pain.
Zander Brandt, shown at his home in the Mission District, learned that all he would owe from the $92,470 in charges from San Francisco General Hospital is a $250 co-pay.

A portrait of Zander Brandt on Wednesday, Jan. 30, 2019, in San Francisco, Calif. Last November, Brandt went to S.F. General hospital with major pain on the side of his stomach. He needed an appendectomy, but minutes before surgery hospital staff told him they were "out-of-network" for his surgery and he'd wind up with a big bill if he went through with it. All other ERs in the city were full so he got the surgery there and now owes $97,000.

Zander Brandt shows a part of the hospital bill of the $97,000 he owes on Wednesday, Jan. 30, 2019, in San Francisco, Calif. Last November, Brandt went to S.F. General hospital with major pain on the side of his stomach. John King of the Department of Water Resources (right) checks the snowpack depth during the second manual snow survey of the season at Phillips Station in El Dorado on Thursday.

John King, of the Department of Water Resources crosses a snow covered meadow during the second manual snow survey of the season at the Phillips station Thursday, Jan. 31, 2019, near Echo Summit, Calif. The survey shows the snow pack at 50 inches deep, with a water content of 18 inches which is 71 percent of average for this location at this time of the year. Statewide the Sierra snowpack is 98 percent of average. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

Department of Water Resources Water Resource Engineer John King checks the weight of the snow sample on a scale held by DWR State Climatologist Dr. Michael Anderson, left , during the first snow survey of the season at Phillips Station, Thursday, Jan. 3, 2019, near Echo Summit, Calif. A second survey on Thursday, Jan. 31, 2019, will show that snow levels in the Sierra Nevada are on par with the long-term average, which is good news, the surveyers say.

Breweries in the Beer-muda Triangle and Sacramento
First let's take a look at the new Beer-muda Triangle breweries. (Click through to continue.)

Three Mile Brewery, Davis 
Unveiled in late February with an alley entrance in downtown Davis, the popular spot is already gearing up for the Davis Bike and Brew Fest and Davis Beer Week, both happening in August. 

In a nod to local history, the name was inspired by the ban on alcohol within a 3-mile radius of the UC Davis campus from 1911 to 1979.

Owned by a group of seven beer enthusiasts, the brewery and taproom was nurtured by a Kickstarter campaign last fall, and currently makes about seven kegs of beer per batch. 

Introductory suds have included a Session IPA, Oatmeal Stout, Barkada Brown ale, Lil’ B Brown, Honey Blonde ale, Saison and a nitrogenated Dry Stout.

Bring your dog if you like; the destination is rustic, with wood and block walls, metal chairs, a concrete floor and a large lighted metal sign reminding us to “drink.” Which we happily do, savoring the sampler presented on a brand-stamped board. 

 231 G St., Suite 3, Davis; (530) 564-4351. www.threemilebrewing.com Hours: 3-10 p.m. Friday, noon-10 p.m. Saturday and noon-8 p.m. Sunday.

Yolo Brewing Company, West Sacramento 
There was good buzz in June 2014 when Yolo Brewing Co. opened its doors in West Sacramento’s Port District. Beer lovers and would-be brewmasters rejoiced, because owner Mike Costello was proprietor of the former Brew It Up restaurant in Davis, which offered a personal brewery option. He’s revived that idea here, with guests invited to make their own beers alongside his own small-batch suds. 

The setting is basic warehouse, but there are lots of distractions beyond sampling the nearly two dozen signature brews, including Hallertauer Lager, Orange Blossom Blonde Ale, DeWit Wild Rice Ale and seasonal Petite Saison. You can fill up at food trucks like Cowtown Urban Eatery, nibble free popcorn, play Jenga, and the best: try your hand at brewing.

Just make a reservation (72 hours in advance for wheat or Belgian beer, to give the crew time to propagate the specialty yeast), then work through a half-day guided crafting session for everything from smooth Dunkel Bock to big, bold Captain Ron’s Double IPA. 

You can also customize recipes, tweaking yeasts or adding extra malt, honey or hops.

Each batch yields about 12.4 gallons, packed in 22-ounce bottles, and costs from $170 to $290, plus $13 per case of refillable bottles. That’s a lot of beer, so Costello recommends sharing the deal with enough friends able to consume the fresh stuff within three months. 

 1520 Terminal St., West Sacramento; (916) 379-7585; www.yolobrew.com Hours: 4-8 p.m. Tuesday and Wednesday, 4-9 p.m. Thursday, 3-9 p.m. Friday, 11 a.m.-9 p.m. Saturday and 11 a.m.-7 p.m. Sunday.

Bike Dog Brewing Company, West Sacramento
This nano-brewery, which opened in October 2013, produces only about 1,000 barrels a year in tiny batches, sending out a rotating collection of taps that might include Three Dog Night Triple IPA, Tantamount Saison, Mosaic Pale Ale, Saison, San Dog IPA, Lowbrau Milk Stout and the powerhouse, a bourbon-barrel-aged Babaris Russian Imperial Stout that comes in at a lusty 11 percent alcohol. 

Owned by entrepreneurs AJ Tendick, Raef Porter, Sage Smith and Pete Atwood, the boisterous place is indeed bike- and dog-friendly, and if your dog can ride a bike, you’ll probably get a free beer. Kick back at a picnic table or at the bar with antique bikes on display and explore, since generous samples are only $2 each. 

Plan to eat, as well, with weekend food trucks such as Culinerdy Cruzer, known for its burger stacked on top of Brussels sprouts slathered in fig-infused balsamic, and fries smothered in basil, pesto, artichoke hearts, fire-roasted tomatoes and spicy sauce.

Come back often, too, to see what’s new. 

Experimentation is the name of the game. “We have done a wet hop beer with local hops, which was great, but sort of a pain to make and really limited, since hops are only fresh once a year,” said Tendick. “We’ve done a coffee version of our Milk Stout with several local roasters, and some local, backyard-harvested grapefruit zest has gone into our San Dog IPA.” 

2534 Industrial Blvd., Suite 110, West Sacramento; (916) 572-0788. www.bikedogbrewing.com Hours: 5-9 p.m. Thursday and Friday, 2-9 p.m. Saturday, and noon-6 p.m. Sunday.

Jackrabbit Brewing Company, West Sacramento
One of the forerunners of the Yolo craft beer movement with its opening in 2011, this brewery focuses on Belgian, English and German-inspired brews via a five-barrel brewing system. But the West Sacramento taproom is shiny new, with an April 2015 grand opening and expansion of production space from 1,500 to 5,000 square feet, including a dog-friendly patio and bar. 

Fancier than other stops with lots of polished wood, gold-tone murals and moody industrial lighting, the vibe is upbeat (witness the playfully themed Ugly Bunny IPA Imperial and Fair Hare golden ale brews) with plenty of humor built around “hoppy” beers. 

New this year are Old Soul Coffee stouts, adding beans from Papua New Guinea and Ethiopia, plus Costa Rica coffee-vanilla and Panama Elida coffee-vanilla in the kegs. Just the thing to go with gyros and falafel from the King Kabob truck that comes by on various weekends. 

1323 Terminal St., West Sacramento; (916) 873-8659. www.jackrabbitbrewingcompany.com Hours: 3-9 p.m. Thursday and Friday, noon-9 p.m. Saturday and noon-6 p.m. Sunday.

Two bull Tule Elks pop their heads up to check their surroundings as they feed at the Grizzly Island Wildlife Area in Suisun, Calif., on Monday, December 21, 2015. The tule elk at Grizzly Island in the Lower Delta have been propagating like champs in the past 35 years. In the late 1970s, the herd started with with just a handful of animals, but as the population expanded at Grizzly Island, individuals were darted, transplanted and used as seed stock to start new herds. The number of elk has expanded from that handful to provide the seed for 21 herds with 3,800 elk around the state. Once numbering close to 500,000, they were all but extinct, but because of the Department of Fish and Wildlife's transplant program, they are thriving.
Credit/Source: Photo: Carlos Avila Gonzalez, The Chronicle

Caption: Attorneys Tobias Keller, left, and Jane Kim of Keller & Benvenutti, one of the firms representing PG&E in its bankruptcy proceedings, enter a federal courthouse in San Francisco Tuesday.

Faced with potentially ruinous lawsuits over California's recent wildfires, Pacific Gas & Electric Corp. filed for bankruptcy protection Tuesday in a move that could lead to higher bills for customers of the nation's biggest utility and reduce the size of any payouts to fire victims. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu)

Paul Zumbro, an attorney with Cravath, Swaine & Moore, one of several law firms representing Pacific Gas & Electric Corp., leaves a federal courthouse in San Francisco Tuesday, the day PG&E filed for bankruptcy. Faced with potentially ruinous lawsuits over California’s recent wildfires, PG&E sought Chapter 11 protection, a move that puts pause on hundreds of legal claims pending on local courts.

Caption: Fresh ravioli has been a staple at Lucca.
Lucca Ravioli Company in San Francisco is closing after 94 years of business.

Credit/Source: Photo: Photos by John Storey / Special to The Chronicle 2016

Caption:
Wing's

The 94-year-old San Jose restaurant quietly closed its doors on February 24. They served Mandarin and Szechuan fare with generous portions.

Lucca Ravioli Company
Lucca Ravioli Company in the Mission announced that they will close their doors on April 20 after a 94 year stint in San Francisco. The Lucca Ravioli Company store manager mentioned owner Michael Feno wants to retire.

The Nantucket
Crockett seafood restaurant, The Nantucket, announced that it would close its doors Feb. 17 after a 89 year stint in the city.

Perennial
After three years in San Francisco, the mid-Market restaurant the Perennial announced it would close on February 9. The owners still plan to pursue the restaurant’s mission via its nonprofit sister organization, the Perennial Farming Initiative.
Credit/Source: Photo: John Storey / Special to The Chronicle

Caption:
Starbucks
Starbucks formerly located at 201 Powell St., closed its doors without warning on January 20. It operated as a 24-hour service business.

Tawla
Tawla closed its doors on Dec.16, 2018, though the closure wasn't made public until Jan. 11. Owner Azhar Hashem said the difficulty in finding workers was linked to the housing market. The restaurant first opened in the Mission District back in 2016.
Credit/Source: Photo: Photos by John Storey / Special to The Chronicle 2016

Caption:
Kome Buffet
Kome Buffet in Daly City shut down the third week of January less than a year after the California Labor Commissioner’s Office cited the restaurant for multiple wage violations in June 2018, resulting in a total fine of $5.16 million.

Picknicky's, Vallejo. Sandwiches for the road? This is your spot. The Sausalito with turkey, bacon and pepper jack is served with chipotle and ranch sauce on sourdough. The Cowboy with pulled pork and provolone is piled with a jalapeno cilantro colesaw on a roll. And the Mr. Lucky is a delicious combination of corned beef and Swiss on sliced rye. 3833 Sonoma Blvd., (707) 552-7000

Newcastle Produce, Newcastle. Right off the freeway, this local grocer and produce stand is a great stop for a quick, healthy bite. You'll find sandwiches, salads, soups, quiche, casseroles, baked goods and espresso drinks at the deli. 9230 Cypress St., (916) 663-2016

Baked and Brewed, Auburn. Need a pick-me-up to keep you going on the road? This coffee shop offers a full espresso bar, pour-over coffees from Santa Cruz Coffee Roasters, baked goods and sandwiches and salads using fresh, daily delivered products and produce. Several gluten-free options. 958 Lincoln Way, (530) 889-1373
Il Pizzaiolo, Colfax. In this small town in the Sierra foothills find thin-crust, blistery pizzas that you'd expect to be served in Naples. 230 S. Auburn St., (530) 388-8412

Monte Vista Inn, Dutch Flat.Right on I-80, this is an old-school place with mountain cabin charm and a comfort-food menu. Try the New York steak with blue cheese, crab cakes, ribs, seafood pasta. It's a sit-down place, so best if you're not in a hurry. And ask for the table with the ocean view--there isn't an ocean obviously, but the waitstaff will make you feel as if there is one. 32106 Ridge Rd., (530) 389-2333
Highway 50 sign suspended over road running through center of country.  (Photo by Diana Walker//Time Life Pictures/Getty Images)
Sierra Smokehouse BBQ, Cameron Park. "Runs circles around every other BBQ joint in Northern Cal for my nickel," says an SFGate reader. 2533 Merrychase Dr., (530) 672-7477

Sweetie Pies, Placerville.Housed in an 1865 Victorian thought to be one of the first homes in Placerville, this spot serves a full breakfast and lunch but is best known for its killer cinnamon rolls. 577 Main St. (530) 642-0128
Credit/Source: Photo: Jason Henry, Special To The Chronicle

Caption: California legislators and other officials expressed frustration with PG&E’s march to bankruptcy.
Assemblyman Chris Holden, D-Pasadena, said he had been seeking to avert a bankruptcy filing by the utility.
Assemblyman Jim Frazier, D-Discovery Bay, introduced a bill to force PG&E to underground more lines.

California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses the results of an investigation that found Pacific Gas & Electric was not responsible for the Tubbs Fire, Thursday, Jan. 24, 2019, in Sacramento, Calif. State fire investigators released a report Thursday saying the deadly 2017 wildfire that scorched Napa and Sonoma counties was caused by a privately maintained electric lines. Newsom said it will be up to PG&E; to decide whether to move ahead with a planned bankruptcy. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)
State Sen. Jerry Hill, D-San Mateo, harshly criticized PG&E.
Gov. Gavin Newsom (left) talks with Assemblyman James Gallagher, R-Yuba City. Gallagher’s district includes an area devastated by the Camp Fire in 2018.

Caption:
Wing's

The 94-year-old San Jose restaurant quietly closed its doors on February 24. They served Mandarin and Szechuan fare with generous portions.

Lucca Ravioli Company
Lucca Ravioli Company in the Mission announced that they will close their doors on April 20 after a 94 year stint in San Francisco. The Lucca Ravioli Company store manager mentioned owner Michael Feno wants to retire.

The Nantucket
Crockett seafood restaurant, The Nantucket, announced that it would close its doors Feb. 17 after a 89 year stint in the city.

Perennial
After three years in San Francisco, the mid-Market restaurant the Perennial announced it would close on February 9. The owners still plan to pursue the restaurant’s mission via its nonprofit sister organization, the Perennial Farming Initiative.
Credit/Source: Photo: John Storey / Special to The Chronicle

Caption:
Starbucks
Starbucks formerly located at 201 Powell St., closed its doors without warning on January 20. It operated as a 24-hour service business.

Tawla
Tawla closed its doors on Dec.16, 2018, though the closure wasn't made public until Jan. 11. Owner Azhar Hashem said the difficulty in finding workers was linked to the housing market. The restaurant first opened in the Mission District back in 2016.
Credit/Source: Photo: Photos by John Storey / Special to The Chronicle 2016

Caption:
Kome Buffet
Kome Buffet in Daly City shut down the third week of January less than a year after the California Labor Commissioner’s Office cited the restaurant for multiple wage violations in June 2018, resulting in a total fine of $5.16 million.

FILE - In this May, 26, 2010 file photo, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg talks about the social network site's new privacy settings in Palo Alto, Calif. Facebook has raised $500 million from Goldman Sachs and a Russian investment firm in a deal that values the company at $50 billion, The New York Times reported. Goldman invested $450 million and Digital Sky Technologies invested $50 million, the newspaper reported Sunday in its online edition, citing people involved in the transaction that it did not name. Goldman has the right to sell part of its stake, up to $75 million, to the Russian firm. (AP Photo/Marcio Jose Sanchez, File)

Caption: Quarterback Joe Montana of the San Francisco 49ers looks to throw upfield in a 20 to16 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals in Super Bowl XXIII on January 22, 1989 in Miami, Florida. This last possesion late in the 4th quarter of the game by the 49ers is known as "The Drive" .

San Francisco 49er head coach Bill Walsh talks to his players at practice here 1/13. The 49ers will play the Cincinnati Bengals 1/22 in Super Bowl XXIII.

San Francisco 49ers head coach Bill Walsh holds his head following his team's Super Bowl win over the Cincinnati Bengals at Joe Robbie Stadium, during a post-game press conference in Miami, Fla., Jan. 23, 1989. Walsh has been expected to announce his resignation as coach, but his future will likely be decided in a meeting with the team owner Eddie DeBartolo this week. Walsh said, "It would be easier to do it now, but I don't want to leave and then come back in nine days and say I changed my mind."
